The Pamela Sporn Papers consist of videos and research materials used by Pamela Sporn in her documentary films. The bulk of the collection consists of approximately 400 digital video files created by Sporn for her film A Humble Giant: 70 Years Defending Immigrants and Radicals, about immigration lawyer Ira Gollobin. These files include interviews and background footage from the documentary, which have been arranged by Sporn by individual and topic. There is also video footage from Ira Gollobin's 2008 memorial service and a 2005 National Lawyers Guild dinner. The collection also includes research files, budgets, fundraising, and promotional materials related to the production of the documentary. In addition to the digital video files, there are DVCAM and MiniDV cassettes that contain additional interviews.

The collection also contains DVDs of Sporn's documentaries With a Stroke of the Chaveta and Disobeying Orders: GI Resistance to the Vietnam War, both of which were produced by her small production company Grito Productions. The collection also includes MiniDV video cassettes of interviews Sporn conducted while producing With a Stroke of Chaveta, which documents the experiences of workers in Cuban cigar factories.

Other materials included in this collection consist of photocopies related to the website Unfriendly Witness: Standing Up to HUAC, which Sporn created to document her family's experience with the House Committee on Un-American Activities (HUAC).

Pamela Sporn is a documentary filmmaker whose films combine personal narratives and archival materials to tell stories about working-class life. Sporn was the daughter of labor activists, leftist scholars, and American Communists. In 1964 her father Paul Sporn gained national attention after he was subpoenaed by the House Committee on Un-American Activities (HUAC), and was represented by Ira Gollobin who later inspired Pamela Sporn's work as a documentarian. Sporn's documentaries generally focus on political resistance and the working class. She has produced several documentaries through her production company Grito Productions, including Disobeying Orders: G. I. Resistance to The Vietnam War (1990); Remembering the Mamoncillo (2007), about Afro-Cuban culture in New York City; With a Stroke of the Chaveta (2007), about Cuban cigar factory workers; Detroit 48202: Conversations Along a Postal Route (2017); and A Humble Giant: Seventy Years Defending Immigrants and Radicals (still in production at the time of donation), about immigration lawyer and activist Ira Gollobin.
Donated by Pamela Sporn in April 2017. The accession number associated with this gift is 2017.023.

Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.
